data.title: added more Android gamepad mappings
Improve readability of the layers flyout panel
data.body:
The layers flyout panel appearance should mirror the docked layer panel. Currently it is almost impossible to detect the difference between what is selected and de-selected. The only difference being a slight change in the gradient used.

If this was changed to a solid black color, it would massively improve its usability and readability. Here is a mockup to illustrate my point:

![layer_gui_proposal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7741669/13275320/c71fc7f0-db07-11e5-80c4-9a313b1029ea.png)

data.title: Add Iterators and use them for for
data.body:
Fixes #3765 . I believe this is a great addition and speedup for GDscript.

The PR does three things, in three commits:
1. Integrate commit by @sheepandshepherd to add a `RangeIterator` class. Many thanks to @sheepandshepherd for writing the class!
2. Add a built in `xrange` function similar to the one in Python 2, and document the function
3. Replace `range` with `xrange` for for loops. This is guaranteed to be 100% backwards compatible, unless you relied on `for i in range(...)` to allocate memory xD... I'm not really proud of how I hacked the parser to do it but this is most conservative regarding backwards compatibility. Note that the `GDParser::_reduce_expression` method does stuff like this as well, so I guess its fine. It catches 99% of all uses. Or do you know somebody who assigns range to a variable and then loops over the variable?

data.title: Steam thinks Godot is still running after I quit
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**

Linux 64-bit, Steam version

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

Steam thinks I am still running Godot after I quit. I tracked it down to this process which remains running in the background: adb -P 5037 fork-server server

If I kill adb, Steam resumes normally.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Launch Godot, do some stuff, quit. Sometimes it's fine. Sometimes it isn't.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Fix typo in error
data.body:
Try the following code:

```
for i in range(0, 10):
print(str("iteration ", i))
```

It will print you a wrong error. Error printing for while loops is not affected, see line 1741 of that file.

data.title: Editor does not throw error while attempting to run game with invalid scene specified
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 10, x86_64 PC, Intel HD Graphics 4000

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I accidentally inserted wrong name into "main scene" field under application settings. Editor didn't notify me about it, instead game's window blinked for a while, then disappeared. After looking into console I saw [this](https://vgy.me/BxG8wE.png). It does not alter editor's behavior afterwards at all, but it's unintuitive, editor should throw a GUI error instead of spamming console.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open project settings.
2. Go into application settings category.
3. Set any scene name that doesn't exist.
4. Launch the game in the editor.

data.title: "Always show close Button In Scene Tab" option is not working correctly

I have tested this on Ubuntu, 2.0 stable
Unfortunately option "Always show close Button In Scene Tab" is not working correctly. 
If we open many scenes and will try to close them while they are not active, the first click will not work, the second one will close two scenes.  You don't need any particular setup to reproduce this.
@StraToN could you take a look?

data.title: Replace Dialog preview bug
data.body:
Ubuntu 64-bit

The Preview shows two "ok" buttons.
At runntime is all fine.

**Steps to reproduce:**

2. Turn/Replace this AcceptDiolog into a ConfirmationDialog.(Resize to see something)

UPDATE: 
Also happens with EditorFileDialog.

2. Turn/Replace this EditorFileDialog into a FileDialog.(Resize to see something)

data.title: Will there be maintenance releases in the 2.0.x branch?
data.body:
[en]
Very surprised at the emergence of a stable version 2.0! Recently I created a couple of bugs that have not yet been closed. And if you look at the current list of errors found it very huge. And all this is already a stable version!
The problem is that version 2.0 is not supported. Found it to correct errors will not be none. They will be corrected in the next version 2.1 already. And when it does not appear clear. And people have to live with supposedly stable version is not known how many. Updated between stable versions of bad practice. And how to live?

[ru]
Очень удивился появлению стабильной версии 2.0! Совсем недавно создал пару багов которые до сих пор не закрыты. И если посмотреть на существующий список найденных ошибок то он очень огромен. И при всем этом уже есть стабильная версия!
Проблема в том что версия 2.0 уже не поддерживается. Найденные в ней ошибки исправлять не кто не будет. Они будут исправляться в уже следующей версии 2.1. А когда она появится не ясно. И людям придется жить с якобы стабильной версией неизвестно сколько. Обновляться между стабильными версиями плохая практика. И как жить дальше?

data.title: Add Density option to the fog parameter
data.body:
Hi

It would have been nice to have a density parameter for the fog. Currently we have falloff and color but density would allow to use fog to add a nice depth effect without occluding completely the world with the fog color.

I made an hard coded test for my own purpose, but of course that would be better to have a slider in the fog parameters in the world environment option.

```

diff --git a/drivers/gles2/shaders/material.glsl b/drivers/gles2/shaders/material.glsl
index ccd80bf..3442569 100644
--- a/drivers/gles2/shaders/material.glsl
+++ b/drivers/gles2/shaders/material.glsl
@@ -1205,7 +1205,7 @@ LIGHT_SHADER_CODE

 #ifdef USE_FOG

-               diffuse.rgb = mix(diffuse.rgb,fog_interp.rgb,fog_interp.a);
+               diffuse.rgb = mix(diffuse.rgb,fog_interp.rgb,fog_interp.a * 0.5);

 # if defined(LIGHT_TYPE_OMNI) || defined (LIGHT_TYPE_SPOT)
                diffuse.rgb = mix(mix(vec3(0.0),diffuse.rgb,attenuation),diffuse.rgb,const_light_mult);

```

data.title: Android Module Compilation
data.body:
I am building a module for android in the newest version of godot , I am using linux , ndk10

when I run scons p=android I get this error 

```
AttributeError: 'SConsEnvironment' object has no attribute 'android_module_file':

```

as the instruction [here](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/reference/creating_android_modules.html?highlight=android) I add my files using 

```
def can_build(plat):
    return plat=="android" or plat=="iphone"

def configure(env):
    if env['platform'] == 'android':
        # will copy this to the java folder
        env.android_module_file("MySingleton.java")
```

I build it before the gradle version of android, I think there is a new way to build module for android but there is no doc or I don't find any.

data.title: Code editor block indent
data.body:
Indenting lines is picky with the first and last selected lines. The **first** lines tab is inserted  where the selection begins. The **last** lines tab is inserted at the beginning, but only if the selection goes past the first character.
I expected the tab characters to be inserted at the beginning of each line touched by the selection.

data.title: Ability in editor to translate node along a single axis (xyz)
data.body: it will be very helpfull if in the editor combining "Move Mode" tool and Shift you can move nodes in vertical or horizontal just like in photoshop.

data.title: Still some metadata in tscn format
data.body:
Follow up of #3060.

@akien-mga:

> There seems to still be one piece of metadata saved: https://github.com/KOBUGE-Games/project-kumquat/blob/fccc7a622e65cbc7a5592a07fbb0c33b5ca8e85c/levels/level.tscn#L11
> `__meta__ = { "__editor_plugin_screen__":"2D" }`
> This one is IMO the most important to get rid of version control-wise, as it changes basically all the time, it just depends whether you pressed Ctrl+S while looking at the script of the 2D screen.
> 
> IMO it might be useful to keep the distinction 2D vs 3D using a meta argument (i.e. whether the scene should open by default the 2D plugin screen or the 3D one?), but maybe we could simply ignore the Script screen?
> Then when saving the scene on the 2D screen, it would define `"__editor_plugin_screen__":"2D"`, on the 3D screen it would define `"__editor_plugin_screen__":"3D"` (just like it does now), but on the Script screen it would keep the previous definition (2D or 3D). WDYT?

@eska014:

> Agree, this `__meta__ = { "__editor_plugin_screen__":"2D" }` is annoying

Maybe just use the scene root node type to determine initial view?
I don't really care for this in the first place, I'd rather do an extra click than make version control more complicated

data.title: Change "erase" to "remove" in project manager. fixes #3796.
Suggestion: Change "erase" wording in project manager to "remove"
data.body: Just a small thing, but to me the word "erase" in the project list always comes across as too extreme. A better choice would be "remove". Even though there is a popup stating that it won't actually be erased from your drive, I feel that "erase" is too harsh a word to use. A new user may be wary of even hitting this button!

data.title: Fix "missing dependency resolver" in Windows
data.body: Fixes #3794

data.title: "Fix Dependencies" dialog opens, but does not work for non-binary scenes types
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Tested on FreeBSD & Win7

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The dialog to fix missing dependencies when opening a scene opens for all scene types, but actually setting a new file is only possible for `.scn` files.

Also, there's a `Fix Broken` button at the top of of the `Fix Dependencies` dialog, does this have any use or can it be removed?

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a new project
2. Add a Sprite root node and set `icon.png` as texture
3. Save scene as .tscn 
4. Close scene
5. Rename `icon.png` to e.g. `icon2.png`
6. Reopen scene
7. In the missing dependency dialog, click `Fix Dependencies`
8. try to fix external resource `icon.png` by reassigning it to e.g. `icon2.png`
9. Observe that reassigning does not work (assigned file does not change)
10. Repeat with .scn -> reassigning works

data.title: Default InputMap action events can't be easily removed
data.body:
**Steps to reproduce:**
- open any project in the editor
- open the project settings and delete one of the events from `ui_accept`
- save
- close the editor and re-open again
- The deleted action is still in the InputMap and engine.cfg

The only way to delete those right now is to add a new temporary action after the removal (which can then also be deleted)

data.title: Suggestion: Bounty Program
data.body:
(sorry if GitHub is not the best place for this, but I dont know where else to post it)

Would be great if we could have a community Bounty Program, as many other free software programs do or have done in the past.

Basically it would work like this:
1 - Godot's team (or any individual person) can select a bug or new feature that they would like to have fixed/implemented (condition: it must exist in the github issues and must be approved by godot's team has something to be fixed/implemented)
2 - Any person can chip in to that bug/feature
3 - once any developer is happy with the amount raised, and he successfully completed it (PR accepted) he would receive the sum

(one other option would be to have the developer himself announce how much he would need to fix it)

Discuss!  :sunglasses:

data.title: Tileable 3D texture not displaying correctly: flags are not saved properly for a JPG texture
data.body:
On a 3d object, I have changed the UV texture to UVform and am trying to get it to tile 2 times. The UV Xform is all set to zero except for xx,yy,zz which are all on 2. I have the "repeat" flag on in the texture.

All looks correct in the 3d viewport exactly a I would suspect. However when I run the game, the "repeat" flag is quite clearly turned off (with the telltale striped stretched texture on the edges) and looks the same as if I had the flag turned off in the viewport.

I have attached a basic project highlighting the bug. When you open this project you will notice that the repeat flag is turned off, but I had saved it with it on! Try turning on the repeat flag, then saving, close down Godot and reload. the flag will have been automaticially turned off.

[uv_repeat_bug.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/139463/uv_repeat_bug.zip)

Viewport screencap
![uvx2_viewport](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7741669/13201001/00af0622-d8b3-11e5-9592-fa4b8e0d9ebd.png)

Ingame screencap
![uvx2_ingame](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7741669/13201004/180b6d24-d8b3-11e5-9ca6-774cca3fbdf2.png)

data.title: docs: RigidBody2D._integrate_forces: Explain in more detail.
data.body: "ll the text talked about "custom integration", so I thought _integrate_forces() was only called if you used set_use_custom_integrator() to enable custom integration and disable internal integration. This attempts to make the actual behavior and use cases a little clearer.

data.title: Blendmodes don't extend to children.
data.body:
Children of a Node2D inherit its visibility, its opacity, etc. But do not inherit its blend mode.

As an example: I'm trying to set up a simple 2D 'spotlight' effect using blend modes and overlays (similar to [this older project made in Flixel](http://gildedgreen.com/cavepals/)).

To this end, I have a Node2D created, with its Blendmode set to multiply, then within that node, I have two sprites, a dark textured overlay, and a light flickering 'spotlight' overlay. I would assume the images within the Node2D would essentially function as a single, multiplying, layer. But, instead, both sprites just use the normal 'mix' blendmode, and are totally opaque, not inheriting their parent's blendmode.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6827480/13198476/6da2a19e-d7d7-11e5-8da9-b2074949e4f7.png)

Actual result:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6827480/13198481/8c11e0c2-d7d7-11e5-941a-1124839b7f8b.png)

Expected result:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6827480/13198487/9f8a4da6-d7d7-11e5-9b21-2334893d28b2.png)

data.title: 2D Rotate tool always resets rotation to zero.
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Win 7, 64 bit. Godot 2.0 RC1. But I'm assuming it works this way for all platforms and all versions. 

**Issue description**
When rotating nodes in the 2D viewport, the rotation always snaps back to zero first, which makes it confusing to use and nearly impossible to make small, precise changes. 

![](http://i.imgur.com/rg7i4P4.gif)

I expect it to add an offset to the current location based on your mouse position. (this is how the 3D rotate tool currently works.)

_P.S. I like the new bug report template._

data.title: Linux export templates link GLU but apparently don't need it
data.body:
When packaging the export templates for Linux with RPM on Mageia, some helper scripts run to check potentially issues, and this warning is raised:

```
Warning: unused libraries in /usr/bin/godot-runner: libGLU.so.1
```

My /usr/bin/godot-runner is the 64-bit version of the Linux export templates (tools=no) built with:
`scons p=x11 tools=no target=release builtin_zlib=no`

I get the same warning for the release_debug templates.

It's not a big issue at all, but if we can fix it, it's always better. Overlinking means that we force all players to have libGLU.so.1 installed even though they don't need it.

I don't get the warning for the tools build, so I guess the editor needs GLU. We just need to hack SCons to only link GLU on tools build (and check if the situation is similar for other platforms, or X11/unix specific).
